awd_titl_txt: EAGER: A Data Flow Approach to Meet the Challenges of Big Data Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation uses the Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) funding mechanism to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This EAGER project was awarded as a result of the invitation in the Dear Colleague Letter NSF 16-080 to proposers from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to submit proposals that would strengthen research capacity of faculty at the institution. The project at Prairie View A & M University aims to implement machine learning algorithms on the data flow architecture and to conduct comprehensive performance and energy consumption studies in comparison with those of classical von Neumann computer architectures. The project outcomes can address the challenges modern computers based on the von Neumann architecture are facing to pertaining memory and power walls in the big data era. 

The project is the first attempt to implement machine-learning algorithms on the data flow architecture. The results of the project will demonstrate if the data flow model can be used successfully to meet the performance, energy efficiency, and scalability requirements of widely used big data analytics and machine learning applications. Once demonstrated, the work can lead to the design and implementation of better and faster high performance computers and Big Data Analytics applications. In addition, the project will also increase the research capability at Historically Black Colleges and Universities in High Performance Computing, Computer Architecture, and Big Data Analytics.

This EAGER project is funded by the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The NSF EAGER project has a direct and significant impact on the diversity of STEM education at Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU). The project has transferred valuable knowledge in the data flow computer architecture, the Fresh Breeze programming model, compiler, and architecture simulation to the PVAMU faculty and students, which has inspired and influenced a group of participant students of African Americans. The project has implemented curriculum enhancements, produced research publications and student presentations, and organized research workshops with MIT and Stony Brook University. The project increased the interests of the underrepresented students in core computer science research. It introduced critical thinking to train students the problem-solving skills from a different perspective other than the traditional model. Perhaps the most significant impact is providing a lens through which underrepresented students can see themselves as successful in core CS research and ultimately as scientists.  

The project also implemented the first machine learning model running on the data flow architecture using Fresh Breeze. The performance evaluation indicates the potential benefits of the data flow architecture in data science applications. The lessons learned and experience gained in the project are invaluable and will continue to increase the research quality and stimulate student interests in STEM at PVAMU. The project fosters collaborations between Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) and the prestigious top-tier research university MIT in applying the new Computer Science architecture to data science application research. The work leads to new funding support from NSF Excellence in Research (HBCU-EiR) program to further study new interdisciplinary big data analytics research. Furthermore, the work also inspired the group of researchers at PVAMU to engage with Scientific Machine Learning research to integrate data science and computational science methodologies.


Last Modified: 01/31/2022
Modified by: Lei Huang
